The Act may be cited as the "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" defines key terms such as casual collecting and Secretary, with the Secretary being either the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Agriculture for National Forest System Lands. The "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" defines terms like Federal lands, Indian lands, and State, specifying lands controlled by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture. The "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" defines terms like Indian tribes, State, and paleontological resource as fossilized remains of organisms providing information about the history of life on earth. The "Paleontological Resources Preservation Act" defines paleontological resources as fossilized remains providing information about the history of life on earth, excluding archaeological materials and cultural items. The Secretary is responsible for managing and protecting paleontological resources on Federal lands using scientific principles. Plans for inventory, monitoring, and use of resources must be developed, emphasizing coordination with non-Federal partners and the public. The Secretary will also establish a public awareness and education program about the significance of paleontological resources. The Secretary may issue permits for collecting paleontological resources on Federal lands, with exceptions for casual collecting on certain lands. Valid permits issued before the enactment of this Act are not affected. Permit issuance is based on specific criteria determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may issue permits for collecting paleontological resources on Federal lands based on specific criteria, including qualifications of the applicant, purpose of furthering knowledge or education, consistency with management plans, and ensuring no threat to natural or cultural resources. Permits will contain necessary terms and conditions. Permits for collecting paleontological resources on Federal lands will include terms such as retaining ownership by the United States, preserving resources for public access, and restricting release of specific locality data without permission. Permits can be modified, suspended, or revoked as necessary. Permits issued for collecting paleontological resources on Federal lands may be modified, suspended, or revoked by the Secretary for various reasons, including resource management, safety concerns, or violations of permit terms. Access to areas under the Secretary's jurisdiction may be restricted or closed to protect resources and ensure public safety. The Secretary may restrict access to or close areas under their jurisdiction to protect paleontological resources and ensure public safety, with the possibility of civil penalties under section 8. SEC. 6. CURATION OF RESOURCES. Paleontological resources collected under a permit must be deposited in an approved repository. The Secretary can make agreements with non-Federal repositories for curation. SEC. 7. PROHIBITED ACTS; CRIMINAL PENALTIES. A person is prohibited from excavating, damaging, or altering paleontological resources on Federal lands without following the regulations. It is also illegal to exchange, transport, export, receive, or sell these resources if they were obtained unlawfully from Federal lands. A person is prohibited from excavating, damaging, or altering paleontological resources on Federal lands without following regulations. It is also illegal to exchange, transport, export, receive, or sell these resources if obtained unlawfully. Violators may face fines, imprisonment, or both as per title 18, United States Code. Violation of regulations regarding paleontological resources on Federal lands can result in fines, imprisonment, or both as per title 18, United States Code. However, there is a general exception for individuals who lawfully possessed the resources before the enactment of the Act. SEC. 8. CIVIL PENALTIES. The Secretary may assess penalties for violations of regulations or permits under the Act, with the amount determined based on factors like the value of the resource and the cost of response and restoration. Each violation is considered a separate offense. The Secretary may assess penalties for violations under the Act based on factors like the value of the resource, cost of response, restoration, and repair, and any other relevant factors. For multiple offenses by the same person, the penalty amount may be doubled. The maximum penalty for any violation is double the cost of response, restoration, and repair, plus double the value of resources destroyed or not recovered. The penalty for violations under the Act can be double the cost of response, restoration, and repair, plus double the value of resources destroyed. Judicial review can be sought within 30 days of the penalty assessment in the United States District Court. Upon filing a petition for judicial review within a 30-day period, the Secretary must promptly submit the record supporting the order. The court will base its decision on substantial evidence from the record. Failure to pay the penalty within 30 days after the order becomes final may result in a court judgment upholding the penalty. The Secretary may request the Attorney General to institute a civil action in a district court to collect the penalty if a final judgment upholds the assessment. The district court will have jurisdiction to decide on the validity, amount, and appropriateness of the penalty. The district court has jurisdiction to hear and decide on actions related to penalties. The validity, amount, and appropriateness of the penalty are not subject to review. Failure to pay penalties may result in additional fees and costs for collection proceedings. Hearings during proceedings must follow section 554 of title 5, United States Code. Penalties collected are available to the Secretary without further action. Penalties collected under this section can be used by the Secretary for protecting, restoring, or acquiring paleontological resources and sites, providing educational materials to the public, and paying rewards as specified in section 9. Section 9 discusses rewards and forfeiture. Section 9 discusses rewards and forfeiture related to penalties collected under sections 7 or 8. The Secretary may pay rewards to individuals providing information leading to civil or criminal violations, with the amount determined by regulations or a set limit. No government officials are eligible for these rewards. All paleontological resources are subject to forfeiture. It also outlines the forfeiture of paleontological resources, vehicles, and equipment involved in violations under sections 7 or 8, subject to civil or criminal forfeiture. Provisions of law regarding seizure, forfeiture, and condemnation of property, as well as procedural provisions of chapter 46 of title 18, United States Code, apply to these seizures and forfeitures. The Secretary can transfer seized paleontological resources to educational institutions for scientific or educational purposes, following the procedural provisions of chapter 46 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 10. CONFIDENTIALITY.

Information about paleontological resources requiring a permit is confidential unless disclosure furthers the Act's purposes, poses no risk to the resource, and complies with other laws.

SEC. 11. REGULATIONS.

The Secretary will issue regulations promptly after the Act's enactment, allowing for public input.

SEC. 12. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. Nothing in this Act shall invalidate, modify, or impose additional restrictions on activities permitted under various mining and land management laws. The Paleontological Resources Preservation Act does not affect activities permitted under existing laws on Federal lands, casual collecting of certain items, recovery from non-Federal lands, or the authority of Federal agencies to protect paleontological resources. The Paleontological Resources Preservation Act does not impact activities allowed on Federal lands, casual collecting, recovery from non-Federal lands, or the authority of Federal agencies to protect paleontological resources. It also prohibits creating rights or benefits for individuals not acting as officers or employees of the United States, and restricts their ability to file civil actions to enforce the Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out the Paleontological Resources Preservation Act.
